speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam. Many people have favourites – a favourite colour, a favourite flavour, a favourite word. What’s yours, Neil?

speaker: nincompoop
text: Hmm, my favourite colour is green, my favourite flavour is sweet-and-sour, and, well, I don’t know if it’s my favourite, but there is a word I really like saying out loud – ‘nincompoop’. It means a silly person.

speaker: Sam
text: For me, it’s the taste of coffee, and the smell of lavender, or freshly baked bread.

speaker: Neil
text: Our favourite tastes, smells and colours are controlled by our five senses – sight, sound, smell, taste, and touch. For most of us they don’t mix. We see colours and taste flavours, but we can’t taste sounds.

speaker: Sam
text: But that’s not how everyone’s brain works. Imagine being able to ‘taste’ every word that you hear. In this programme, we’ll meet two sisters from Glasgow in Scotland who can do just that. And as usual, we’ll learn some new vocabulary as well.

speaker: synaesthesia
text: Julie McDowall and her younger sister, Jen McCready, have synaesthesia, a neurological condition where two or more senses mix together. When synesthetes, as they’re called, hear a word, their sense of taste also becomes activated. Words produce specific tastes on their tongues. For example, when Jen hears the name of her daughter, Sophia, she tastes pink marshmallows! And the name ‘Leo’ tastes like noodles.

speaker: Sam
text: We’ll hear more from the unusual sisters later, but first I have a question for you, Neil. We’ve just heard what happens when Jen McCready hears the names ‘Sophia’, and ‘Leo’, but what does she taste when she hears the name ‘Neil’?

speaker: Sam
text: a) eggs and bacon

speaker: Sam
text: b) spaghetti hoops

speaker: Sam
text: c) a jam sandwich?

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I don’t know what this says about me, Sam, but I’m going to guess that it’s c) a jam sandwich.

speaker: Sam
text: OK. Don’t worry, Neil - I’ll reveal the answer later in the programme. Synaesthesia isn’t only about people, like Julie and Jen, who taste words - it can be a mixing of any of our senses. A synesthete may hear colours or see sounds. In fact, there could be as many as 150 different types of synaesthesia.

speaker: Neil
text: For the Scottish sisters, having synaesthesia is a gift, something Jen explained when she talked with BBC World Service programme, The Food Chain:

speaker: cravingvivid
text: This is enjoyable, it’s never anything that causes … the only thing I would say is it’s quite hard if you’re trying to eat healthily because if you hear a word that maybe tastes like tuna, I’ll be like, ‘Oh, I need to get a tune baguette now’… You know, it’s almost like being pregnant and having a craving… words can be so vivid that you want to eat that – that’s the only negative I would say about it.

speaker: craving
text: For Jen, the only drawback to synaesthesia is that it can be hard to eat healthily because hearing certain words produces a craving – a strong feeling of wanting a particular food.

speaker: vivid
text: That could be because, for Jen, the sound of the word is so vivid – clear, detailed, and powerful in her mind.

speaker: Sam
text: There’s still much doctors don’t know about why some people experience sense mixing while most of us experience each sense in isolation, but it’s clear that for Julie and Jen, synaesthesia makes the world a more interesting, colourful place.

speaker: Neil
text: Someone who can explain why so little is known about synaesthesia is Guy Leschziner, consultant neurologist at King's College London, and author of the book, ‘The Man Who Tasted Words’. Here he is speaking to BBC World Service’s, The Food Chain:

speaker: dismissed,overactive imagination
text: One of the problems with synaesthesia is for many years it’s been dismissed, and it’s been viewed as people with an overactive imagination, something not real but actually what research in recent years has taught us is that actually it does have an underlying neurological and genetic basis.

speaker: dismissed overactive imaginations
text: Guy says that in the past, synaesthesia was often dismissed – considered unimportant or uninteresting. Synesthetes were labelled people with overactive imaginations – a tendency to imagine things that are not true.

speaker: Neil
text: But research is showing that the causes of synaesthesia could run in the family.  Julie and Jen’s brothers don’t have synaesthesia, but Jen’s daughter does. And with an estimated 4% of the world population having some form of sense mixing, a world of new and exciting possibilities is opening up to millions.

speaker: Sam
text: Exciting possibilities like tasting someone’s name… Remember in my question I asked what synesthete, Jen McCready, tastes when she hears the name ‘Neil’.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. Well, I guessed that ‘Neil’ tastes like a jam sandwich. Was I right?

speaker: Sam
text: Well, Neil, no - you don’t taste like a jam sandwich. In fact, when Jen hears the name ‘Neil’, she tastes spaghetti hoops! Oh well, it could be worse – the name ‘Robert’ makes Jen taste rotten eggs! Sorry to any Roberts listening.

speaker: synaesthesia
text: OK, let’s recap the vocabulary we’ve learned in this programme about synaesthesia – a neurological condition where two or more senses mix together.

speaker: nincompoop
text: A nincompoop is an informal way of saying a silly person.

speaker: craving
text: A craving for something is the strong desire to have it.

speaker: vivid
text: A vivid sensation is clear, strong and detailed in your mind.

speaker: dismissed
text: When something is dismissed, it’s considered unimportant or uninteresting.

speaker: overactive imagination
text: And finally, an overactive imagination is the tendency to imagine things that are not true. Once again, our six minutes are up! If you’ve enjoyed this look into the weird and wonderful world of synaesthesia, we hope you’ll join us again next time for more chat, interesting issues and useful vocabulary here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now!

speaker: Neil
text: Goodbye!
